habitat_description:
Populations of the round-tailed horned lizard extend from southeastern Arizona, New Mexico, southeastern Colorado, and northern Texas into San Luis Potosi, Mexico (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999; Degenhardt et al. 1996; Dixon 2000; Hammerson 1999; Rondeau 2002; Stebbins 2003). The elevational range has been reported to occur from approximately 210 to 2200 meters (Degenhardt et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003).

In general, this species occupies desert, grassland, herbaceous habitats, shrubland, and chaparral where it prefers areas of sparse vegetation, gravelly to rocky soils, bajada slopes, desert flats, arid and semiarid hills, and edges of washes. This is a species that burrows in or using soil, also found occupying rodent burrows. Individuals have been reported basking or resting on the ground surface, while eggs are laid in soil or underground (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999; Degenhardt et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003).

Primarily occupies areas of sparse vegetation where cover is provided by soil, decaying vegetation, and rocks.
